title: Auditory Nerve Involvement: Case 4-1
chief_complaint: I am unable to hear over the phone when holding it to my right ear.

problem_summary.onset: Progressive symptoms over the past year.
problem_summary.course: Progressive hearing loss; symptoms appeared to worsen during the year before evaluation.
problem_summary.laterality: Right ear primarily; slight hearing difficulty noted in left ear on audiogram but patient focused on right.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Occasional high-pitched tinnitus in the right ear; slight momentary imbalance on turning quickly.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Inability to use the telephone with the right ear.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Initially sought help from a hearing aid dealer, then referred for consultation.

history.present_illness: Healthy 61-year-old male presenting with progressive right-sided hearing loss, right-sided high-pitched tinnitus, and momentary imbalance when turning quickly.
history.otologic_history: No specific prior otologic history noted other than current symptoms.
history.noise_exposure_history: No noted history of noise exposure.
history.prior_management: Patient initially contacted a hearing aid dealer but was referred for audiologic consultation.
history.patient_goals: Diagnosis and management of hearing loss.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear shows moderate to severe sensorineural hearing loss. Left ear shows mild to severe sensorineural loss commencing at 2000 Hz.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear spondee thresholds established with difficulty; patient could not recognize monosyllabic words at any intensity. Left ear showed good speech recognition.

numeric_results.RE_WRS_NU6: CNT (Could Not Test) / 0% recognition mentioned in text

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Contralateral reflexes present at normal levels for Left Ear stimulation. Right Ear stimulation showed elevated or absent reflexes.

tests.name: Auditory Brainstem Response (ABR)
tests.key_findings: Right ear showed no repeatable tracings at high intensities (80-90 dB nHL). Left ear demonstrated normal absolute latencies for waves III and V (Wave I not identified).

tests.name: CT Scan
tests.key_findings: CT of right petrous pyramid with interthecal air injection. Air did not fill the Internal Auditory Meatus (IAM), indicating a mass. Axial cut showed mass extending into the Cerebellopontine Angle (CPA).

overall_audiologic_summary: This 61-year-old male presents with a classic retrocochlear profile on the right side. Audiometry reveals a moderate-to-severe SNHL in the right ear with disproportionately poor speech recognition (0% / CNT). Acoustic reflexes are elevated/absent with right ear stimulation, and ABR shows no repeatable waves on the right despite high intensity stimulation. The left ear shows high-frequency SNHL but preserved speech recognition and normal ABR latencies. Imaging confirmed a mass filling the right IAM and extending into the CPA, consistent with an acoustic tumor.
counseling_points: Explain the discrepancy between the pure tone hearing loss and the inability to understand speech on the right side (retrocochlear pathology).
Discuss the results of the ABR and Reflex testing indicating neural involvement.
Review the radiological findings confirming the presence of a mass (acoustic tumor) on the auditory nerve.
Refer to Otolaryngology/Neurosurgery for management of the acoustic tumor (surgical removal was performed in this case).
notes_for_actor: You are frustrated that you cannot use the phone on your right ear at all.
You have noticed a high-pitched ringing (tinnitus) in your right ear.
You occasionally feel off-balance if you turn your head too fast.
You have no history of working in loud noise.
You tried to buy a hearing aid first, but the seller told you to see an audiologist instead.
